Abandoned

Change 56769 satisfied the ask from this change (expose Item.)
As such the request from this change is satisfied and this change is not needed
nit: missing space
Done

Please add more details on how this change effects all platforms (ideally making the required changes to the config files for the mainboards effected).  Considering that EVERY system has a BMC, how would a user use this?  Where would the user add it?  How does it get used by other services?
Added some more description.

Can you please check a "full" example, including a baseboard, dcscm module, and this content into an EM review somewhere.  It doesn't have to be complete, but given that this is non-trivial, we need to figure out how to model it.

Ack

Will also try to come up with some example that cover the different possible fields ("HasBMC", "SubItem")
Updated an example in change 55907.
I'm not sure what the FRU EEPROM has to do with things?
They are only included here to show that existing Configurations can be exposed together with the newly-introduced Inventory.Item's.
Gotcha.  Lets omit it for the moment.

Type, as a field should not include the dbus interface.  If you look at the dbus interface this produces, this would produce something like:

xyz.openbmc_project.Configuration.xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.BMC, which is I don't think it what you intended.

This change allows a user to expose a `Configuration` as well as an `Item` and requires the user to fully-qualify the `Item` (thus the check in line 727.)

I'm not sure about what a better solution should look like ..

Type: "BMC"

would be generally how we would model it.

I see, so with the current code structure, checking the name "BMC" would be in step 6) of the traversal process with some refactoring in this change due to how 6) calls the other 2 functions (populateInterfaceFromJson and postValuesToDbus):

```
1) postToDBus
2) for (auto& [boardId, boardConfig] : newConfiguration.items())
3)   populateInterfaceFromJson populates json::{number,string}
4)   postValuesToDbus populates json::object
5)     for (auto& item : *exposes)
6)       postExposedItemToDbus
7)         (If applicable to the "expose an Inventory.Item" hack)
8)           populateInterfaceFromJson populates json::{number, string}
9)           postValuesToDbus populates json::object
10)        (Otherwise, treat as exposing a Configuration)
11)          populateInterfaceFromJson populates json::{number, string}
  
```

For "HasThisBMC", it would be inserted to 3) as it is a property of the board .json.

This is assuming most of the possibilities fall into the scope of the postToDBus function.

(note: phosphor-dbus-interfaces uses "Bmc" rather than "BMC")

I'm not sure what this is trying to represent.  The BMC is not on a slot, and on the DC-SCM system you're working on, I would expect the "BMC" node to be on the DC-SCM board itself, not on the "superboard"
This line is purely for showing that "a property can be added to the exposed `Inventory.Item` object and its contents do not carry any meaning.
Lets just omit this for the moment.  As-written, it doesn't look right for any system, and I suspect that will confuse people.
Ack

can't you just do

```
"xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Bmc":{
  "CCC": "DDD",
}
```

and such?
Something like that would be nice, since "CCC" is meant to be a property under the Item.Bmc interface.

Exposes record in an exposes record?  Please takea  look, this doesn't seem like it's what you intended, and I can't tell if it's just a copy/paste error or what the deal is.  I'm would assume a name of "Invalid" isn't what you intended.
This is just a contrived wrong configuration for showing that such configurations are rejected by the code in this change list.

In examples, lets try to focus on things that we would expect to see.  Yes, error handling is important, but lets keep the error handling examples relegated to unit tests if we can, so people don't make the same mistake I did and think they're a valid example.
Ack
This is a random property for showing the existing functionality of E-M works normally. It's now removed to avoid confusion.
?  The nested field shouldn't really exist.  We have patterns for having "sub" objects using the Found() probe type, that lets us split stuff up.  This looks like it's duplicating that?

It looks like the Found() probe type doesn't create sub-objects; the object created and the object that serves as the Found() probe are on the same level (board/boardA and board/boardB, rather than "board/boardA/boardB").

The intent of Exposing an Inventory.Item does not supersede the practice of splitting items into multiple .json files, for example in the intended use case, the Exposed item (BMC) usually cannot be split from its board using regular methods.

> probe are on the same level (board/boardA and board/boardB, rather than "board/boardA/boardB").

You mean the dbus interfaces?  Yes, all entities are flat on dbus;  That's the intent so that entities can be removed and added without their child objects being added or removed.


> The intent of Exposing an Inventory.Item does not supersede the practice of splitting items into multiple .json files, for example in the intended use case, the Exposed item (BMC) usually cannot be split from its board using regular methods.

This detail would've been really helpful in your commit message.
Added to the commit message (difference between this change and splitting into 2 json files).

One thing I wonder a little is if we can automatically detect any of this.  Presumably, everything running OpenBMC has a BMC, so does it make sense to make edits to every single mainboard file to add a BMC inventory item?

I think it depends on the viewpoint.
From the conciseness point of view, editing every file is too redundant and doesn't make sense.
From the completeness point of view, we're just describing the boards in a bit more detail, so it makes sense.

I think if the BMC cannot autonomously determine its physical location (I am not sure with my current knowledge), this information needs to be injected in some form, maybe by adding a BMC entry to the .json configs or some other methods.

> I think it depends on the viewpoint.
> From the conciseness point of view, editing every file is too redundant and doesn't make sense.
> From the completeness point of view, we're just describing the boards in a bit more detail, so it makes sense.
> 
> I think if the BMC cannot autonomously determine its physical location (I am not sure with my current knowledge), this information needs to be injected in some form, maybe by adding a BMC entry to the .json configs or some other methods.

Agreed.  I wonder if we need to promote "This is the config this bmc lives on" to a higher scope so we can do stuff like this without having to edit every baseboard file.

To avoid having to edit every baseboard file, it would be good if the BMC has some way to localize itself. A few ways that I know about:

One possibility is to examine the existing association graph. I took a look at some existing systems, this method doesn't guarantee a 100% precise result, since it appears association edges may be arbitrarily specified:

* For some platform without a DC-SCM module that comes with multiple boards: the board that has the BMC also has a few BMC margin sensors associated with it, while the other boards do not.

* For some platform with a DC-SCM module: A sensor appears to be including the DC-SCM module's name and "bmc" (the snapshot was obtained a while back, I'm not sure the meaning in the names ..)

Another possibility ... if the BMC can tell the interface used by the BMC<->host IPMI communication, it may be easier to guess which inventory the BMC is contained in. "ipmipci" probably indicates the BMC is on a DC-SCM module; "ipmilpc" probably indicates the BMC is on the motherboard. This, plus the association graph, may give some heuristics for the BMC to figure out its own location.

So the conclusion is I don't yet have a very good idea on how to enable the BMC to localize itself with what I currently know, but I can take a closer look at the "association graphs" or add a small program to test the "heuristics".
If there are no existing mechanisms (like a function call) to do this, this becomes a research question, in my understanding.

According to discussion on Discord, the user should indicate in the .JSON configuration which Board contains the current BMC.

Updated this change accordingly.

Opened a new change for allowing the user to indicate the board containing the "current BMC", in response to the discussion on August 10:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/56769
Please avoid default parameters in this case, it makes it less clear what all the other calling code does.
Ack
I'd really prefer we not special case hardcoded names in the config.  This makes me wonder if we modeled the config files properly.

How about:

1. Add a new flag "HasBMC" for board .json's that indicate the board has a BMC on it (it effectively replaces the "Exposes:[{"Type":"Bmc","Name":"Bmc"}]" snippet in the Exposes field)

2. Add a new flag "SubItems" to differentiate from the "Exposes" field (all objects in SubItems are prepended with "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item." while all objects in Exposes are still prepended with "xyz.openbmc_project.Configuration."

> How about:
> 
> 1. Add a new flag "HasBMC" for board .json's that indicate the board has a BMC on it (it effectively replaces the "Exposes:[{"Type":"Bmc","Name":"Bmc"}]" snippet in the Exposes field)

Can you post an example somewhere?  Also, can we make the parameter "HasThisBMC" or something that indicates that it's not just "a" bmc, but literally the bmc we're running on (systems commonly have multiple bmcs).

Assuming I'm visualizing what you're talking about, this seems like the way I would go.

> 
> 2. Add a new flag "SubItems" to differentiate from the "Exposes" field (all objects in SubItems are prepended with "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item." while all objects in Exposes are still prepended with "xyz.openbmc_project.Configuration."

If this is a route you want to go down, lets talk through it, but it seems like a case where we would want multiple files (or maybe multiple definitions in one file) with associations between them to denote their connectedness, but, lets scope out what you're thinking and see if we can come to something similar.

I added the following snippets in the JSON file "ASRock_E3C246D4I" as an example for the different ways to add a BMC:

* Method 1: An "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item" entry in the "Exposes" stanza (this is going to be removed per the comments ..)
* Method 2: A "HasThisBMC" flag in the board JSON
* Method 3: A "SubItems" stanza allowing the user to create sub-items that exist as children DBus objects. Same as Exposes except that all items created will be Inventory.Item's rather than Configurations.

I'm not sure which one is the best or if this change is to be considered together with other proposals such as 52487 (association interfaces for cables), and the discussion on Discord on April 15 (PhysicalLocation's). Please advise?
I separated this change and moved the sample JSON change to change 55907.
Sorry about this;  I had draft comments that have been in draft since march 21st.  If they no longer apply, please let me know.
Updated examples of the 3 possible methods in ASRock_E3C246D4I.json and some description in the change log.
